OUTPUT: ["Delicious - A good meal can be described as delicious when it is full of flavor and satisfies one's taste buds.", 'Satisfying - A satisfying meal leaves you feeling content and fulfilled after eating, with no hunger pangs or cravings left to satisfy.', 'Hearty - A hearty meal often implies a substantial amount of food that is filling and comforting.', "Wholesome - A wholesome meal means it's nutritious, healthy, and promotes well-being for the body.", 'Delectable - This term suggests a gourmet or luxuriously flavorful meal that is highly enjoyable to eat.', 'Flavorsome - A good meal has an array of tastes and textures, making it flavorsome and interesting to the palate.', 'Nutritious - A nutritious meal provides all the essential vitamins, minerals, and other important nutrients that are beneficial for health.', 'Scrumptious - This word describes a delicious meal that is especially appetizing or mouth-watering.', "Succulent - A succulent dish means it's juicy, flavorful and tender, making the eating experience delightful.", 'Palatable - A good meal must be palatable, meaning it tastes pleasant and agreeable to eat.', 'Appetizing - An appetizing meal looks appealing and invites one to taste its flavorsome qualities.', 'Inviting - An inviting meal makes you want to dig in because of its aroma, presentation, or promise of great taste.', 'Tasty - A tasty meal delights the senses with its enjoyable and pleasurable flavors.', 'Exquisite - An exquisite meal is not only beautifully presented but also features exceptionally well-crafted, complex flavors.', 'Gourmet - This term refers to an elegant, sophisticated, and high-quality meal prepared with great skill and care.', 'Delectable Feast - A delectable feast suggests a large or abundant meal that is exceptionally delicious.', 'Epicurean - An epicurean meal caters to the refined tastes of those who appreciate culinary art and fine foods.', 'Satiating - A satiating meal completely satisfies hunger, leaving no desire for additional food until the next mealtime.', 'Nourishing - A nourishing meal provides comfort and energy to the body while also being nutritious.', 'Culinary Delight - A culinary delight refers to a gastronomic experience where every aspect of the dish is exceptionally well-prepared and pleasurable to eat.']

['Turban - A cylindrical scarf-like cloth worn on top of the head, typically by men in various cultures and religions.', 'Fez - A felt hat with a conical crown, traditionally associated with Middle Eastern culture and Islamic dress.', "Kippah - A small, round cap worn to cover one's head as a sign of respect towards God, commonly used by Jewish men.", 'Yarmulke - Another term for a kippah, originating from the Sephardic Jewish community.', 'Mitre - The ceremonial head-dress worn by bishops and certain abbots in Christian churches.', "Papal tiara (Papal crown) - A jeweled three-tiered crown that was formerly used as a papal headdress, though it's no longer utilized since 2005.", 'Mitren - A type of Byzantine hood or headpiece with protruding ridges and often adorned with jewels.', 'Crown (headgear) - A decorative headdress worn by kings, queens, princes, and sometimes even other high-ranking members of royalty as a symbol of authority.', 'Corona (crown in Latin) - Refers to the ceremonial headpiece used in religious liturgies or state functions, often adorned with precious metals and gemstones.', 'Phrygian cap - An ancient conical cap associated with freed slaves and Roman republicans, but also adopted by revolutionaries for symbolic purposes.', 'Tzitzit (Hebrew) - A fringed or tassel-like garment worn on a prayer shawl as part of Jewish religious observance; often referred to in terms of its headdress role.', 'Keffiyeh - A traditional Middle Eastern headscarf, typically white with red and black checks, which can also be considered a formal headdress in certain contexts.', 'Turbanette (Turban-style hat) - A modernized version of the turban that incorporates elements from various cultures or fashion trends.', 'Shia Taqiyah (Arabic: طاقية شيعية) - An Islamic skullcap worn by many Muslim men, particularly those in Shiite communities; considered a formal headdress for religious and daily wear.', 'Hijab (Head covering) - A head-and-chest-covering worn by some Muslim women as an expression of modesty or privacy']

['Octet - A group of eight people or things, commonly used in music (e.g., an octet refers to a musical ensemble consisting of eight instruments).', 'Octagon - An eight-sided polygon with equal sides and angles, often found in architecture and design.', 'Eightfold Path - The central teaching of Buddhism that describes the path towards enlightenment, involving eight practices or aspects.', 'Eight Precepts - In Buddhism, these are ethical guidelines for monastics to follow during special observances; it includes abstaining from eating after noon and engaging in sexual activity.', 'Octal - A base-8 number system, using eight digits (0-7).', 'Octave - In music, a doubling or halving of the frequency between two notes that sound harmonious when played together; an interval spanning eight diatonic scale steps.', 'Octopus - An eight-limbed marine creature with soft body and tentacles used for locomotion and catching prey.', 'Octave-group (or octave band) - In acoustics, a frequency range of sound that is divided into bands spanning an octave; often used in audio analysis or filtering systems.', 'Eight Men Out - A 1986 film about the Black Sox Scandal involving eight Chicago White Sox players who were banned from professional baseball for conspiring to fix the World Series.', "Octane - Refers to an octane rating, which measures a fuel's resistance to 'knocking,' or premature explosion inside an engine; in this context it can also represent groups of eight (e.g., high-octane fuels).", 'Octavian - A Roman Emperor and adoptive son of Julius Caesar, ruling from 27 BC to 14 AD.', "Eight Fathers' Daughters - An ancient Japanese ritual where eight fathers would bring their daughters to a shrine for blessings; nowadays it is primarily observed as a funeral ceremony.", 'Octavium (or octaval) - A term used in the 18th and early 19th century referring to a group of eight people or things, often associated with nobility or importance (e.g., "The Octavians").', 'Eight-card hand - In card games like poker, it refers to any grouping of cards that comprises eight unique cards.', "Octant - A tool used for measuring angles up to 45 degrees in navigation; originally referring to a quarter (22.5 degree) part of the horizon circle on a ship's compass.", 'Eightfold Root of All Existence - In Buddhism, it refers to eight aspects or qualities essential to enlightenment: right view, intention, speech, action, livelihood, effort, mindfulness and concentration.', 'Octavo - A term used in bookmaking, referring to a size that is one-eighth of the full sheet of paper; often associated with early printed books from the 15th century onward.', 'Eight Lights - An ancient Chinese divination system where eight different lights were interpreted as omens or signs for various purposes.', 'Octet (or octette) - A term used to describe a group of eight, often in music; can refer to an ensemble or piece with eight instruments/voices.', 'Eight-headed Dragon - In mythology and folklore, it refers to dragons with eight heads, which are said to possess immense power or wisdom.']

CLUE: Flavoured cornflour used to make a yellow sauce
OUTPUT: ['Cornstarch - A pure, unflavored starch derived from corn, often used as a thickening agent in cooking and baking.', 'Flour - An unprocessed grain product that can be flavored or unflavored and is the base ingredient for many sauces including those made with cornflour.', 'Mayonnaise - A common condiment often thickened using cornstarch, but not inherently yellow in color unless other ingredients are added.', 'Mustard - A flavorful condiment that can be mixed into a yellow sauce, although it does not contain cornflour.', 'Custard - An egg-based dessert thickened with starch (including cornflour) but is neither used to make a specifically "yellow" sauce nor inherently yellow without additional flavoring or coloring agents.', 'Roux - A mixture of flour and fat, which can be made from cornstarch instead for a gluten-free option; it\'s a common base in many thickened sauces but does not typically match the "flavored" criterion.', 'Flambé - A technique to cook food with alcohol over high heat, often involving pan drippings and flour as well (not specifically cornflour).', "Hollandaise Sauce - An emulsion of egg yolks, butter, and lemon juice; it doesn't use cornstarch for thickening and is not inherently yellow without additional seasoning or coloring agents.", "Cheese Sauce - Often uses a starch like flour to achieve the desired consistency but isn't specifically flavored with cornflour, nor does it always have a yellow hue.", 'Bechamel Sauce - A classic French sauce made from milk and white roux (using wheat flour), not directly related to cornstarch or its flavoring.', 'Béchamel Sauce with Cheese - An adaptation of the basic bechamel, sometimes includes cheese for additional flavor, but it\'s typically thickened with flour rather than cornflour and doesn\'t match the "yellow sauce" requirement without further modification.', "Cornmeal - A coarsely ground variant of cornflour that can be used in recipes to provide texture or as a base for certain types of grits, but isn't directly associated with making yellow sauces.", 'Polenta - Prepared from cornmeal and water/stock; while it is made from corn products, polenta is typically not flavored nor used as a yellow sauce in culinary applications.', "Masa Harina - A fine ground corn flour traditionally used for making tortillas; although related to the concept of cornflour, it doesn't align with the clue given regarding flavoring and making a yellow sauce.", 'Tapioca Starch - While sometimes used in cooking as a thickener like cornstarch, tapioca starch itself is not inherently flavored or specifically associated with creating yellow sauces.', "Ketchup (adjusted) - A tomato-based condiment that can be seasoned to achieve a yellow color; however, it does not typically incorporate cornflour for thickening and isn't traditionally considered in the context of this clue.", "Grits - Similar to polenta but made with ground hominy rather than regular cornmeal; grits are more about texture and aren't directly related to yellow sauces or flavored cornflour.", "Jalapeño Puree (adjusted) - A spicy ingredient that can be used to add flavor and color, yet it doesn't fit the profile of a starch-based sauce.", 'Cinnamon Sugar - An unrelated seasoning typically used for sweet applications like desserts or breakfast pastries; does not meet the criteria as neither related to cornflour nor yellow sauces.', "Paprika - A spice that can add a vibrant red hue to dishes, and although it might be present in some flavored recipes, on its own it doesn't relate directly to using cornflour or creating a yellow sauce."]
